text: Medical image analysis has experienced an explosion of interest in the past decade.
The ability to recognize subtle pathologies in medical images is of paramount importance in the clinic.
As such, medical image analysis is heavily driven by artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, including deep networks (DN) and machine learning (ML).
This paper reviews the use of ML and DN for medical image segmentation.

A broad variety of techniques is reviewed, ranging from traditional methods that rely on manual image annotation to emerging semisupervised, self-supervised, and unsupervised DN architectures that aim at alleviating the need for manual image annotation.

The recent surge of attention to medical image segmentation can be attributed to the availability of an increasing number of large training image datasets, accompanied by a surge in computing capabilities.
Deep network architectures are particularly good at learning highlevel features in medical images and perform comparatively well with machine learning and other AI techniques.

Deep network training is now affordable with the help of Graphic Processing Units and specialized computer architectures such as graphics processing unit neural network (GPNN) and Graphics processing units (GPUs).

The emergence of self-supervised and unsupervised DN architectures is expected to further reduce the burden of manual image annotation to train large-scale DN models used in complex imaging techniques involving multiple image input modalities.
The promise of this research is to enable the training of DN models with limited supervision, which can be used in the clinic to facilitate accurate pathology detection in medical images.
